Question can be broken down into two elements. A) what will be the new "constant" level of working from home post-pandemic. B) the number of workers forced to work from home due to the COVID-19 pandemic in this time period. Unless there is a sudden dramatic increase in Coronavirus cases heading into winter we can expect the number working from home to trend down towards A as has been occurring over the last few months. I'm not sure what A is and am unsure as to how to go about estimating it. Cannot be absolutely certain that this new level of WFH might lie above 15%. Have noted a slight slowdown in the pace of decline of wfh but it now stands at 17%. I think a yes answer is most likely but there are many things that could knock this off course and my cautious 55% forecast reflects this. Will revise in later October which might offer more clarity.

As a fellow forecaster mentioned, the UK did loosen their travel restrictions and with more people getting the vaccine it could slightly change things. However, with the new variants and the current discussion over how effective the vaccine will be at fighting them, I still believe that chances of work from home rates falling is less likely.

As the number seems to be consistently above 20% for the last few weeks, it is likely that the percentage won't drop below 15% by 18Dec2021. However, given that the UK have eased their travel restrictions, the workforce might also be expected to go back. This would bring the number closer to the pre-Covid levels which was below 15%.

One the one hand, the number of people that worked "mainly from own home" was around 5% before the pandemic [1], and I agree with others here who think that number won't exceed 10%, so 15% seems reachable in a world where life would go back to the pre-pandemic normal before 18/12. On the other hand, the trend seems rather flat (the average never went below 21% since the start of June), and there was no signal in it from restrictions on home working being lifted in England (which has the largest share of both the working population and homeworkers) on 19/07. Totally agree that this needs monitoring as more numbers come out after the school holidays. Yet, even if 1/4th of the workforce is currently on holidays, were to return to work now and not answer "worked from home and didn't travel to work", the number would not drop below 15%. All considered, I'll start slightly on the skeptical side until there is more data.

Despite COVID-19 working from home is a world wild tendency so the numbers will not drop so much until December, maybe I would bet that the percentage will increase or not significantly change in the period.

For ease of understanding, let's divide the working population into two classes - 
1.) People WFH for more than year - These people have been wfh for more than year now and have developed kind of a fatigue to less human interaction and robotic kind of work environment. They will probably shift to hybrid work environment.
2.) New joiners - These are people generally more enthusiastic about new work and want to meet and see their team. They are more likely to go to office and get to know the culture.
These two categories of people point towards more people shifting out permanent WFH. The major percentage of people who will continue permanent WFH are the ones who have shifted to their hometowns away from the offices and won't plan on coming to office.

This is a % of all those who said they were working. In order for this number to go down from 21% to 15% or lower, one or more of the other numbers needs to go up. That is unlikely:
* Unlikely that the pandemic gets so much worse that a lot of people are on sick leave so they don't work from home and don't travel for work. Even in that case, it is likely that the % that travel to work gets smaller.
* Unlikely that the pandemic gets so much better that much fewer people work from home. Even in the summer of 2020 the number wasn't that low. And people like to work from home, so some will continue.
* Unlikely that the economy gets much worse that a lot of people are furloughed.
